revisions.rev:
{{Infobox national football team | Name = England Under-16 | Flag = Flag of England.svg | Badge = England crest 2009.svg | FIFA Trigramme = ENG | Nickname = Three Lions/England Schoolboys | Association = [[The Football Association]] | Confederation = [[UEFA]] (Europe) | Coach = {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Kenny Swain]] | pattern_la1= |pattern_b1= _eng11h|pattern_ra1= |pattern_so1= _englandh2010 | leftarm1=FFFFFF|body1=FFFFFF|rightarm1=FFFFFF|shorts1=003399|socks1=FFFFFF | pattern_la2= |pattern_b2= _englanda2011|pattern_ra2= |pattern_sh2= |pattern_so2= _englanda2011| | leftarm2=1E1E1E|body2=1E1E1E|rightarm2=1E1E1E|shorts2=6DACDF|socks2=1E1E1E }} '''England national under-16 football team''', also known as [[England]] under-16s or England U16(s), represents [[England]] in [[association football]] at a under-16 age level and is controlled by [[the Football Association]], the governing body for [[football in England]]. The current manager is [[Kenny Swain]], who was appointed in August 2004.{{cite news|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/U16s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2004/08/EnglandU16_KennySwain.htm|title=Brooking boosts set-up|date=6 August 2004|publisher=[[The Football Association]]|accessdate=2009-02-17}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==Competition history== The England under-16 team compete in the annual [[Victory Shield]] tournament against [[Scotland national under-16 football team|Scotland]], [[Wales national under-16 football team|Wales]] and [[Northern Ireland national under-16 football team|Northern Ireland]]. Since [[World War II]], England have won the Victory Shield outright thirty-four times and have been joint winners with Scotland eight times, with Wales twice and with both Scotland and Wales twice. They are the current champions.{{cite news|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/U16s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/VictoryShieldSchedule08.htm|title=The Victory Shield 2008|year=2008|publisher=[[The Football Association]]|accessdate=2009-02-17}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In 2005, the team made their debut in the annual Montaigu Tournament, held in [[Montaigu, VendÃ©e|Montaigu]], [[France]].{{cite news|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/U16s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2005/03/EngU16_Swain_PreMontaagu.htm|title='A tremendous experience'|last=Wright|first=James|date=22 March 2005|publisher=[[The Football Association]]|accessdate=2009-02-17}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} England have won the competition twice, in 2008 and 2011. On both occasions, they met the hosts [[France national football team|France]] in the final, beating them in a penalty shoot-out after a 0-0 draw.{{cite news|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/U16s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/england_france_report|title=Lions win tournament|date=24 March 2008|publisher=[[The Football Association]]|accessdate=2009-02-17}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u16s/News/match-centre/2011/EngFra11/Report?p=mr&mid=170247|title=Lions capture Montaigu crown|date=25 April 2011|publisher=[[The Football Association]]|accessdate=2011-04-26}} ==Fixtures & results 2011–12== ===Victory Shield=== {{main|2011 Victory Shield}} {|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !width=165|Team !width=20|Pld !width=20|W !width=20|D !width=20|L !width=20|GF !width=20|GA !width=20|GD !width=20|Pts |- bgcolor=gold |align=left|{{fbu|16|ENG}} |3||3||0||0||11||3||+8||'''9''' |- |align=left|{{fbu|16|WAL}} |3||1||1||1||3||5||−2||'''4''' |- |align=left|{{fbu|16|NIR}} |3||1||0||2||4||7||−3||'''3''' |- |align=left|{{fbu|16|SCO}} |3||0||1||2||3||6||−3||'''1''' |} {{footballbox collapsible |date = 12 October 2011 |time = 19:35 [[UTC+1]] |team1 = {{fbu-rt|16|ENG}} |team2 = {{fbu|16|NIR}} |score = 3 â 1 |result = W |goals1 = Hunte {{goal|17}}
